titles: 12.2 — Solving a system of linear equations

post.title: 11.2 — Interpolation & Curve fitting
post.content:
Motivation

  • We often want to analyze data points in the form shown below, where we have some dependent variables yiy_iyi​ corresponding to some independent variables xix_ixi​.
x0x_0x0​
x1x_1x1​
x2x_2x2​
.........
xnx_nxn​
y0y_0y0​
y1y_1y1​
y2y_2y2​
.........
yny_nyn​
  • The goal is to find a function f(x)f(x)f(x) that either
    • passes through all the points exactly (interpolation)
    • approximates data in a “best” possible way but not exactly (curve fitting)

Image from Kiusalaas, chap. 3.

How interpolation and curve-fitting are useful?

  • If we can find a function f(x)f(x)f(x) that interpolates or approximates the data well,
    • We can try to predict new data points (xk,yk)(x_k, y_k)(xk​,yk​).
    • We can better understand the underlying process that might have generated the data.

Polynomial interpolation

  • The simplest form of interpolation function is a polynomial function.
  • It is always possible to construct a polynomial P(x)P(x)P(x) of degree nnn that passes through n+1n+1n+1 data points.

Lagrange’s method

  • Suppose we have a dataset of n+1n+1n+1 points:

    (x0,y0),(x1,y1),(x2,y2),...,(xn,yn)(x_0, y_0), (x_1, y_1), (x_2, y_2), ..., (x_n, y_n)(x0​,y0​),(x1​,y1​),(x2​,y2​),...,(xn​,yn​)

  • We construct an interpolation polynomial of degree nnn, called the Lagrange polynomial, using the formula:

    P(x)=c0(x)y0+c1(x)y1+...+cn(x)ynP(x) = c_0(x)y_0 + c_1(x)y_1 + ... + c_n(x)y_nP(x)=c0​(x)y0​+c1​(x)y1​+...+cn​(x)yn​

    where ci(x)c_i(x)ci​(x) are called the cardinal functions.

  • The cardinal functions are given by:

    ci(x)=(x−x0)(xi−x0)⋯(x−xi−1)(xi−xi−1)⋅(x−xi+1)(xi−xi+1)⋯(x−xn)(xi−xn)=∏j=0j≠in(x−xj)(xi−xj)\begin{aligned} c_i\left( x \right) &= \frac{(x-x_0)}{(x_i-x_0)} \cdots \frac{(x-x_{i-1})}{(x_i-x_{i-1})} \cdot \frac{(x-x_{i+1})}{(x_i-x_{i+1})} \cdots \frac{(x-x_{n})}{(x_i-x_{n})}\\[1em] &= \prod_{\substack{j = 0 \\[.1em] j \neq i}}^{n} \frac{(x-x_j)}{(x_i-x_j)} \end{aligned}ci​(x)​=(xi​−x0​)(x−x0​)​⋯(xi​−xi−1​)(x−xi−1​)​⋅(xi​−xi+1​)(x−xi+1​)​⋯(xi​−xn​)(x−xn​)​=j=0j=i​∏n​(xi​−xj​)(x−xj​)​​
    • Numerator contains all terms except (x−xi)(x - x_i)(x−xi​)
    • Denominator contains all terms except (xi−xi)(x_i - x_i)(xi​−xi​)

Claim: P(x)P(x)P(x) passes through each data point

If P(x)P(x)P(x) passes through all points (xi,yi)(x_i, y_i)(xi​,yi​), then we must have:

P(xi)=yiP(x_i) = y_iP(xi​)=yi​

Let’s see if this is true for the Lagrange polynomial we just found.

In the above equation for ci(x)c_i(x)ci​(x), setting x=xix=x_ix=xi​ and x=xjx=x_jx=xj​, i≠ji \ne ji=j, we have

ci(xi)=∏j=0j≠in(xi−xj)(xi−xj)=1c_i\left( x_i \right) = \prod_{\substack{j = 0 \\[.1em] j \neq i}}^{n} \frac{(x_i-x_j)}{(x_i-x_j)} = 1ci​(xi​)=j=0j=i​∏n​(xi​−xj​)(xi​−xj​)​=1

and

ci(xj)=∏j=0j≠in(xj−xj)(xi−xj)=0 , j≠ic_i\left( x_j \right) = \prod_{\substack{j = 0 \\[.1em] j \neq i}}^{n} \frac{(x_j-x_j)}{(x_i-x_j)} = 0\ ,\ j \neq ici​(xj​)=j=0j=i​∏n​(xi​−xj​)(xj​−xj​)​=0 , j=i

Now, using the equation of P(x)P(x)P(x) for x=xix=x_ix=xi​:

P(xi)=c0(xi)y0+...+ci(xi)yi+...+cn(xi)yn=0+...+1⋅yi+...+0=yi\begin{aligned} P(x_i) &= c_0(x_i)y_0 & &+ ... + c_i(x_i)y_i & &+ ... + c_n(x_i)y_n \\ &= 0 & &+ ... + 1\cdot y_i & &+ ... + 0 \\ &= y_i \end{aligned}P(xi​)​=c0​(xi​)y0​=0=yi​​​+...+ci​(xi​)yi​+...+1⋅yi​​​+...+cn​(xi​)yn​+...+0​

Lagrange polynomial — Example

Consider the following dataset. We have 444 data points so the degree of the Lagrange polynomial P(x)P(x)P(x) will be n=3n=3n=3.

xix_ixi​
000
101010
202020
303030
yiy_iyi​
−250-250−250
000
505050
−100-100−100

We first write 444 cardinal functions corresponding to these 444 data points using x-values.

c0(x) = (x−10)(0−10)⋅(x−20)(0−20)⋅(x−30)(0−30) = −16000x3+1100x2−1160x+1c1(x) = (x−0)(10−0)⋅(x−20)(10−20)⋅(x−30)(10−30) = 12000x3−140x2+310xc2(x) = (x−0)(20−0)⋅(x−10)(20−10)⋅(x−30)(20−30) = −12000x3+150x2−320xc3(x) = (x−0)(30−0)⋅(x−10)(30−10)⋅(x−20)(30−20) = 16000x3−1200x2+130x\begin{aligned} c_0(x) \ &= \ \frac{(x-10)}{(0-10)} \cdot \frac{(x-20)}{(0-20)} \cdot \frac{(x-30)}{(0-30)} \ = \ \frac{-1}{6000}x^3 + \frac{1}{100}x^2 - \frac{11}{60} x + 1\\ c_1(x) \ &= \ \frac{(x-0)}{(10-0)} \cdot \frac{(x-20)}{(10-20)} \cdot \frac{(x-30)}{(10-30)} \ = \ \frac{1}{2000}x^3 - \frac{1}{40}x^2 + \frac{3}{10} x\\ c_2(x) \ &= \ \frac{(x-0)}{(20-0)} \cdot \frac{(x-10)}{(20-10)} \cdot \frac{(x-30)}{(20-30)} \ = \ \frac{-1}{2000}x^3 + \frac{1}{50}x^2 - \frac{3}{20} x\\ c_3(x) \ &= \ \frac{(x-0)}{(30-0)} \cdot \frac{(x-10)}{(30-10)} \cdot \frac{(x-20)}{(30-20)} \ = \ \frac{1}{6000}x^3 - \frac{1}{200}x^2 + \frac{1}{30} x \end{aligned}c0​(x) c1​(x) c2​(x) c3​(x) ​= (0−10)(x−10)​⋅(0−20)(x−20)​⋅(0−30)(x−30)​ = 6000−1​x3+1001​x2−6011​x+1= (10−0)(x−0)​⋅(10−20)(x−20)​⋅(10−30)(x−30)​ = 20001​x3−401​x2+103​x= (20−0)(x−0)​⋅(20−10)(x−10)​⋅(20−30)(x−30)​ = 2000−1​x3+501​x2−203​x= (30−0)(x−0)​⋅(30−10)(x−10)​⋅(30−20)(x−20)​ = 60001​x3−2001​x2+301​x​

We then use these four cardinal functions along with the y-values yiy_iyi​ in the equation of P(x)P(x)P(x):

P(x)=c0(x)y0+c1(x)y1+...+cn(x)yn=−x2+35x−250\begin{aligned} P(x) &= c_0(x)y_0 + c_1(x)y_1 + ... + c_n(x)y_n \\ &= -x^2 + 35x -250 \end{aligned}P(x)​=c0​(x)y0​+c1​(x)y1​+...+cn​(x)yn​=−x2+35x−250​

Download file lagrange_polynomial.py from Ed to plot these points and the interpolation function to check if it works.

Curve fitting

  • If data is obtained experimentally, there could be random noise present due to measurement errors.
    • Interpolation would not be a good choice as it would fit all data points including noise as well.
  • Instead, we use curve fitting, to find a smooth curve that fits the “average” of the data points, and that is less affected by the noise or “outlier” points.

Linear regression

  • Linear regression is a simpler case of curve fitting where a straight line is found that fits a set of data points.

  • Unlike interpolation, the line need not pass through the points.

  • Linear regression line is given by f(x)=ax+bf(x) = ax + bf(x)=ax+b, where aaa is the slope of the line, and bbb is the y-intercept.

  • The main task will be to find aaa and bbb such that the line “fits” the data points in the “best” possible way.

How to determine the “best” fit?

  • To know how good a line fits the given data points, we compute error for each data point.

  • Error is defined as the squared difference between the actual y-value yiy_iyi​ and the y-value given by the regression line, f(xi)f(x_i)f(xi​).

  • The total error EEE for all data points is given by

    E(a,b)=∑i=0n(yi−f(xi))2=∑i=0n(yi−(axi+b))2\begin{aligned} E(a, b) &= \sum_{i=0}^{n} \left ( y_i - f\left ( x_i \right ) \right ) ^ 2 \\ &= \sum_{i=0}^{n} \left ( y_i - \left ( ax_i + b \right ) \right ) ^ 2 \end{aligned}E(a,b)​=i=0∑n​(yi​−f(xi​))2=i=0∑n​(yi​−(axi​+b))2​

  • One way to define “best” fit:

    • Given all the data points (xi,yi)(x_i, y_i)(xi​,yi​), we want to find a line (i.e. find aaa and bbb) such that the error E(a,b)E(a, b)E(a,b) is minimized.

  • To find aaa and bbb that minimize E(a,b)E(a, b)E(a,b), we calculate the partial derivatives of EEE with respect to aaa and bbb:

∂E∂a=0,     ∂E∂b=0\frac{\partial E}{\partial a} = 0,\, \, \, \, \, \frac{\partial E}{\partial b} = 0∂a∂E​=0,∂b∂E​=0

Calculating the partial derivatives

∂E∂a=∑i=0n2(yi−(axi+b))(−xi)\frac{\partial E}{\partial a} = \sum_{i=0}^{n} 2 (y_i - (ax_i + b)) (-x_i)∂a∂E​=i=0∑n​2(yi​−(axi​+b))(−xi​)
∂E∂b=∑i=0n2(yi−(axi+b))\frac{\partial E}{\partial b} = \sum_{i=0}^{n} 2 (y_i - (ax_i + b))∂b∂E​=i=0∑n​2(yi​−(axi​+b))

Setting above derivatives to 000 and solving for aaa and bbb,

a=∑(xi−xˉ)(yi−yˉ)∑(xi−xˉ)2a = \frac{\sum (x_i - \bar{x}) (y_i - \bar{y}) } {\sum (x_i - \bar{x})^2 }a=∑(xi​−xˉ)2∑(xi​−xˉ)(yi​−yˉ​)​
b=yˉ−axˉb = \bar{y} - a\bar{x}b=yˉ​−axˉ

where xˉ\bar{x}xˉ and yˉ\bar{y}yˉ​ are the averages of x-values and y-values of data points.

Finally, using these aaa and bbb, we get the desired best-fit line as f(x)=ax+bf(x)=ax+bf(x)=ax+b. Here aaa is slope of the line and bbb is the y-intercept.

Download linear_regression.py from Ed, which plots data and regression line.
